solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the sale price of bicycle from each deal.

**Deal A**

If the price is reduced by $25 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 25 = 75 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Sale price from Deal A}     &= 75 \% \ \text{of} \ 260 \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {75} {100} \times 260   \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {75 \times 260 } {100}  \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {25 \times 3 \times 4 \times 65 } {25 \times 4}  \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {\cancel{25} \times 3 \times \cancel{4} \times 65 } {\cancel{25}  \times \cancel{4}}   \\\\
                                  &= 3 \times 65 \\\\
                                  &= \pounds 195
\end{aligned}
$

**Deal B**

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Sale price from Deal B}     &= \pounds 205
\end{aligned}
$

Better deal $= \text{Deal A} = \pounds 195$

There are $14$ boys in year $4$.

Given that $\dfrac{2}{5}$ of the year are boys, how many are girls?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of students in year $4 = a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{2}{5} \times a                          &= 14  \\\\
\dfrac{2 \times a}{5}                          &= 14  \\\\
a                                              &= \dfrac{14 \times 5}{2} \\\\
                                               &= \dfrac{7 \times 2 \times 5}{2} \\\\
                                               &= \dfrac{7 \times \cancel{2} \times 5}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
                                               &= 7 \times 5 \\\\
                                               &= 35
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total children}   &= 35 \\\\
\text{Total girls}      &= \text{Total children} - \text{Total boys} \\\\
                        &= 35 - 14  \\\\
                        &= 21
\end{aligned}
$

a                                   &= 12
\end{aligned}
$

The number that Gino thought of $= 12$.

\begin{aligned}
4 \times 5 + c \times 3       &= 44 \\\\
20 + 3c                       &= 44 \\\\
3c                            &= 44 - 20 \\\\
3c                            &= 24 \\\\
c                             &= \dfrac {24} {3} \\\\
c                             &= \dfrac {3 \times 8} {3} \\\\
c                             &= \dfrac {\cancel 3 \times 8} {\cancel 3} \\\\
c                             &= 8
\end{aligned}
$

Number of children $= 8$

The table shows Ann's marks in two tests.

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the percentage score for both the tests.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Test } 1       &= \dfrac {60}{80} \times 100 \\\\
                     &= \dfrac {60 \times 100}{80} \\\\
                     &= \dfrac {15 \times 4 \times 20 \times 5}{20 \times 4} \\\\
                     &= \dfrac {15 \times \cancel{4} \times \cancel{20} \times 5}{\cancel{20} \times \cancel{4}} \\\\
                     &= 15 \times 5 \\\\
                     &= 75 \% \\\\
\text{Test } 2       &= \dfrac {70}{100} \times 100 \\\\
                     &= 70 \%
\end{aligned}
$

Ann did better in Test $1$.

questions.question:
If $2$ apples and $1$ banana cost $\pounds 1.20$

and

$1$ apple and $2$ bananas cost $\pounds 1.35$, find the cost of an apple and a banana separately.
questions.answer:
Cost of an apple $= \pounds 0.35$

Cost of a banana $= \pounds 0.50$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the cost of an apple $= a$

Let the cost of a banana $= b$


As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
2a + b &=  1.20 \\\\
a + 2b &= 1.35
\end{aligned}
$

We have got $2$ variables and we have $2$ equations to solve them. Let's eliminate to reduce it to just one variable.

Multiply the second equation by $2$.

$
\begin{aligned}
2 \times a + 2 \times 2b     &= 2 \times 1.35 \\\\
2a + 4b                      &= 2.70
\end{aligned}
$

Subtract the first equation from the second to reduce it to one variable.

$
\begin{aligned}
2a + 4b - (2a + b)     &= 2.70 - 1.20 \\\\
2a + 4b -2a  -b        &= 1.50 \\\\
3b                     &= 1.50 \\\\
b                      &= \dfrac {1.50} {3} \\\\
b                      &= \pounds 0.50
\end{aligned}
$

Cost of a banana $= \pounds 0.50$

Let's substitute the value of $b$ in one of the initial equations to find the cost of an apple.

$
\begin{aligned}
2a + b     &=  1.20 \\\\
2a + 50    &=  1.20 \\\\
2a         &=  1.20 - 0.50 \\\\
2a         &=  0.70 \\\\
a          &= \dfrac {0.70} {2} \\\\
a          &= \pounds 0.35
\end{aligned}
$

Cost of an apple $= \pounds 0.35$

If the price is reduced by $30 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 30 = 70 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of 2 chairs from Shop A}     &= 70\% \times 600 \times 2 \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac{70}{100}  \times 600 \times 2  \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac{70 \times 600 \times 2}{100} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac{70 \times 6 \cancel{0} \cancel{0} \times 2}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\\\
                                        &= 70 \times 6 \times 2 \\\\
                                        &= \pounds 840
\end{aligned}
$

**Shop B**

If the price is reduced by $\dfrac{1}{5}$, then the sale price will be $1 - \dfrac{1}{5} = \dfrac{4}{5}$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of } 2 \text{ chairs from Shop B}    &= \dfrac{4}{5} \times 550 \times 2 \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac{4 \times 550 \times 2}{5} \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac{4 \times 5 \times 110 \times 2}{5} \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac{4 \times \cancel{5} \times 110 \times 2}{\cancel{5}} \\\\
                                                &= 4 \times 110 \times 2 \\\\
                                                &= \pounds 880
\end{aligned}
$

**Shop C**

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of } 2 \text{ chairs from Shop C}     &= \pounds 820
\end{aligned}
$


Cheapest price $= \text{Shop C} = \pounds 820$

                         &= 2 \times 2 \times 6 \times 2 \\\\
                         &= 48
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
George had a bag full of $24$ apples.

-  He gave half of them to his Granny to make an apple pie.
-  He gave two thirds of what was left to his friends and then put the rest in the fruit bowl.

How many did he put in the fruit bowl?

solutionDetails.working:
If George gave $\dfrac {1} {2}$ to his Granny, then he is left with $1 - \dfrac {1} {2} = \dfrac {1} {2}$ of the apples. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Apples left}     &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 24 \\\\
                        &= 12
\end{aligned}
$

If George gave $\dfrac {2} {3}$ to his friends, then he is left with $1 - \dfrac {2} {3} = \dfrac {1} {3}$ of the remaining apples. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Apples left in the fruit bowl}     &= \dfrac {1} {3} \times 12 \\\\
                                          &= 4
\end{aligned}
$

Number of apples left in his fruit bowl $= 4$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Apples left in the fruit bowl} &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times \dfrac {1} {3} \times 24 \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {24} {2 \times 3} \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {4 \times 2 \times 3} {2 \times 3} \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {4 \times \cancel{2} \times \cancel{3}} {\cancel{2} \times \cancel{3}} \\\\
                                      &= 4
\end{aligned}
$

Number of apples left in the fruit bowl $= 4$

questions.question:
Emilie is thinking of a number. If she

-  adds $2$ to it,
-  then squares it
-  and then subtracts $4$ she gets $60$.

Circle the number that Emilie was thinking of.

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number Emilie thought of $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
(a + 2 ) ^ {2} - 4     &= 60 \\\\
(a + 2 ) ^ {2}         &= 60 + 4 \\\\
(a + 2 ) ^ {2}         &= 64 \\\\
a + 2                  &= \sqrt {64} \\\\
a + 2                  &= 8 \\\\
a                      &= 8 - 2 \\\\
a                      &= 6
\end{aligned}
$

Number that Emilie thought is $= 6$.

solutionDetails.working:

\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of persons}    &= \dfrac {\text{Total pizzas}} {\text{Pizza per person}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {8} { \dfrac {2} {3}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {8 \times 3} { 2} \\\\

                            &= \dfrac {4 \times \cancel{2} \times 3} {\cancel{2}} \\\\
                            &= 4 \times 3 \\\\

a                                               &= 3 \times 180 \\\\
a                                               &= 540 \ \text{g}
\end{aligned}
$

Each ticket cost $\pounds 480$.

|:-------------:|:-----------------------------------:|
| Super Tickets |         Buy $2$ get $1$ free        |
|  Tickets R US | Buy $3$ get $25 \%$ off total price |
| Ticket Galore |    Buy $1$ get $2$ at $40 \%$ off   |
|   Top Ticket  |      Buy $2$ get $1$ half price     |


<svg width="200" height="200" viewBox="0 0 200 200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Pie chart slice">
  <circle cx="100" cy="100" r="70" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <path d="M100 100 L100 30 A70 70 0 0 1 165 120 Z" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
</svg>


If I needed $3$ tickets, put the vendors in order (cheapest first).
questions.answer:
- Super Tickets
- Ticket Galore
- Tickets R US
- Top Ticket

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the best price of $3$ tickets from each vendor.

**Super Tickets**

The third ticket is free when you buy $2$ tickets. So, the cost of $3$ tickets is just the cost of $2$ tickets.

$
\begin  {aligned}
\text{Cost of } 3 \text{ tickets}     &= 480 \times 2 \\\\
                                      &= \pounds 960
\end{aligned}
$

**Tickets R US**

If the total price is reduced by $25 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 25 = 75 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Cost of} \ 3 \ \text{tickets}       &= 75\% \times 480 \times 3 \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{75}{100} \times 480 \times 3 \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{75 \times 480 \times 3}{100} \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{25 \times 3 \times 4 \times 120 \times 3}{25 \times 4} \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{\cancel{25} \times 3 \times \cancel{4} \times 120 \times 3}{\cancel{25} \times \cancel{4}} \\\\
                                           &= 3 \times 120 \times 3 \\\\
                                           &= \pounds 1080
\end{aligned}
$

**Ticket Galore**

If the price is reduced by $40 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 40 = 60 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Cost of} \ 3 \ \text{tickets}      &= 480 + 60\% \times 480 \times 2 \\\\
                                          &= 480 + \dfrac{60}{100} \times 480 \times 2 \\\\
                                          &= 480 + \dfrac{60 \times 480 \times 2}{100} \\\\
                                          &= 480 + \dfrac{6\cancel{0} \times 48\cancel{0} \times 2}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\\\
                                          &= 480 + 6 \times 48 \times 2 \\\\
                                          &= 480 + 576 \\\\
                                          &= \pounds 1056
\end{aligned}
$


**Top Ticket**

If the price is reduced by $\dfrac{1}{2}$, then the sale price will be $1 - \dfrac{1}{2} = \dfrac{1}{2}$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of} \ 3 \ \text{tickets}      &= 480 \times 2 + \dfrac{1}{2} \times 480 \\\\
                                         &= 960 + \dfrac{480}{2} \\\\
                                         &= 960 + \dfrac{240 \times 2}{2} \\\\
                                         &= 960 + \dfrac{240 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
                                         &= 960 + 240 \\\\
                                         &= \pounds 1200
\end{aligned}
$

Put these fractions in ascending order of size, show workings.

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text {First} &= \dfrac{3}{5} \ \text{of} \ 30 \\\\
              &= \dfrac{3}{5} \times 30 \\\\
              &= \dfrac{3 \times 6 \times 5}{5} \\\\
              &= \dfrac{3 \times 6 \times \cancel{5}}{\cancel{5}} \\\\
              &= 18 \\\\
\text {Second}  &= \dfrac{7}{10} \ \text{of} \ 20 \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7}{10} \times 20 \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7 \times 20}{10} \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7 \times 2 \times 10}{10} \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7 \times 2 \times \cancel{10}}{\cancel{10}} \\\\
                &= 14 \\\\
\text {Third}  &= \dfrac{2}{3} \ \text{of} \ 24 \\\\
&= \dfrac{2}{3} \times 24 \\\\
&= \dfrac{2 \times 24}{3} \\\\
&= \dfrac{2 \times 8 \times 3}{3} \\\\
&= \dfrac{2 \times 8 \times \cancel{3}}{\cancel{3}} \\\\
&= 16
\end{aligned}
$

Arrange the results in ascending order.

$
\begin{aligned}
& 14 < 16 < 18 \\\\
& \dfrac{7}{10} \ \text{of} \ 20 < \dfrac{2}{3} \ \text{of} \ 24 < \dfrac{3}{5} \ \text{of} \ 30
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
Given that two teas and a coffee cost $ \pounds 2.50$ and one tea and three coffees cost $ \pounds 3.50$.

How much does a single coffee cost?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the cost of a cup of tea $= t$

Let the cost of a cup of coffee $= c$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
2t + c &= 2.50 \\\\
t + 3c &= 3.50
\end{aligned}
$

We have got $2$ variables and we have $2$ equations to solve them. Let's eliminate to reduce it to just one variable.

Multiply the second equation by $2$.

$
\begin{aligned}
2 \times t + 2 \times 3c &= 2 \times 3.50 \\\\
2t + 6c &= 7.00
\end{aligned}
$

Subtract the first equation from the second to reduce it to one variable.

$
\begin{aligned}
(2t + 6c) - (2t + c) &= 7.00 - 2.50 \\\\
2t + 6c - 2t - c &= 4.50 \\\\
5c &= 4.50 \\\\
c &= \dfrac {4.50} {5} \\\\
c &= \pounds 0.90
\end{aligned}
$

Cost of a cup of coffee $= \pounds 0.90$.

Let the length of the bridge $= L \ \text{m}$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Portions over banks}  &= \dfrac{L}{4} + \dfrac{L}{3} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{3L}{4 \times 3} + \dfrac{4L}{3 \times 4} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{3L}{12} + \dfrac{4L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{7L}{12} \\\\
\text{Portion over river}   &= L - \dfrac{7L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{12L}{12} - \dfrac{7L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5 \times 84}{12}  \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5 \times 7 \times 12}{12}  \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5 \times 7 \times \cancel{12}}{\cancel{12}}  \\\\
                            &= 35 \ \text{m}
\end{aligned}
$

If the amount is reduced by $10 \%$, then the reduced value will be $100 - 10 = 90 \%$ of the original value. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
&= 90 \% \ \text {of} \ \text 44 \\\\
&= \dfrac {90} {100} \times 44 \\\\
&= \dfrac {90 \times 44} {100} \\\\
&= \dfrac {3960} {100} \\\\
&= \pounds 39.60
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
A box contains bags of crisps.

Each bag of crisps weighs $25 \ \text{grams}$.

Altogether, the bags of crisps inside weigh $1 \ \text{kg}$.

How many bags of crisps are inside the box?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of bags of crisps $= b$


The weight of box is given in kg and weight of crisp bag is given in grams. Lets convert weight of box in grams.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total weight of the bags}         &= 1 \ \text{kg} \\\\
                                        &= 1 \times 1000 \ \text{grams} \\\\
                                        &= 1000 \ \text{grams}
\end{aligned}
$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
b \times 25                 &= 1000 \\\\
b                           &= \dfrac {1000} {25} \\\\
b                           &= \dfrac {25 \times 40} {25} \\\\
b                           &= \dfrac {\cancel {25} \times 40} {\cancel {25}} \\\\
b                           &= 40
\end{aligned}
$

Number of bags of crisps inside the box $= 40$

                               &= \dfrac {652} {45} \\\\

\end{aligned}
$

The **perimeter** of a regular hexagon is $42a + 18$.
Write an expression for the lengths of one of its sides.


<svg width="320" height="80" viewBox="0 0 320 80" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Number line">
  <line x1="20" y1="40" x2="300" y2="40" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="20" y1="32" x2="20" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="20" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">0</text>
<line x1="76" y1="32" x2="76" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="76" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">1</text>
<line x1="132" y1="32" x2="132" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="132" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">2</text>
<line x1="188" y1="32" x2="188" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="188" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">3</text>
<line x1="244" y1="32" x2="244" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="244" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">4</text>
<line x1="300" y1="32" x2="300" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="300" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">5</text>
</svg>

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Length of one side}   &= \dfrac {\text{Perimeter}} {\text{Number of sides}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {42a + 18} {6} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {6 \times 7a + 6 \times 3} {6} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {6 \times (7a + 3)} {6} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {\cancel 6 \times (7a + 3)} {\cancel 6} \\\\
                            &= 7a + 3
\end{aligned}
$

Length of one side $= 7a + 3$.

children.question:
The **perimeter** of a different regular polygon is $75b - 20$.
The length of one of its sides is $15b - 4$.
How many sides does the regular polygon have?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of sides}   &= \dfrac {\text{Perimeter}} {\text{Length of one side}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {75b - 20} {15b - 4} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {5 \times 15b - 5 \times 4} {15b - 4} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {5 \times (15b - 4)} {15b - 4} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {5 \times \cancel {(15b - 4)}} {\cancel {15b - 4}} \\\\
                            &= 5
\end{aligned}
$

Number of sides $= 5$.

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of blue counters = b

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{b}{6 + 6 + b}    &= \dfrac {1} {5} \\\\
\dfrac{b}{12 + b}       &= \dfrac {1} {5} \\\\
5b                      &= 12 + b \\\\
5b - b                  &= 12 \\\\
4b                      &= 12 \\\\
b                       &= \dfrac {12} {4} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {4 \times 3} {4} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {\cancel {4} \times 3} {\cancel {4}} \\\\
                        &= 3 \\\\
\text{P(red)}           &= \dfrac {6} {6 + 3 + 6} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {6} {15} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 3} {3 \times 5} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times \cancel{3}} {\cancel{3} \times 5} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2} {5} \\\\
\text{P(green)}         &= \dfrac {6} {6 + 3 + 6} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {6} {15} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 3} {3 \times 5} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times \cancel{3}} {\cancel{3} \times 5} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2} {5}
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
The perimeter of a regular hexagon is $42a + 18$.

Write an expression for the length of one of its sides.


<svg width="240" height="160" viewBox="0 0 240 160" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Angle">
  <line x1="60" y1="120" x2="180" y2="120" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="60" y1="120" x2="140" y2="50" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <path d="M90 120 A30 30 0 0 1 82 97" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <text x="85" y="105" font-size="14">θ</text>
</svg>

solutionDetails.working:
Let the side of the hexagon $= s$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
6 \times s  &= 42a + 18 \\\\
6s          &= 42a + 18 \\\\
s           &= \dfrac {42a + 18} {6} \\\\
s           &= \dfrac {6 \times 7a + 6 \times 3} {6} \\\\
s           &= \dfrac {6 \times (7a + 3)} {6} \\\\
s           &= \dfrac {\cancel {6} \times (7a + 3)} {\cancel {6}} \\\\
s           &= 7a + 3
\end{aligned}
$

Length of the one side of hexagon $= 7a + 3$.

children.question:
The perimeter of a different regular polygon is $75b - 20$.

The length of one of its sides is $15b - 4$.

How many sides does this regular polygon have?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of sides in polygon $= n$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
n \times (15b - 4)  &= 75b - 20 \\\\
n                   &= \dfrac {75b - 20} {15b - 4} \\\\
n                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 15b - 5 \times 4} {15b - 4} \\\\
n                   &= \dfrac {5 \times (15b - 4)} {15b - 4} \\\\
n                   &= \dfrac {5 \times (\cancel {15b - 4})} {\cancel {15b - 4}} \\\\
n                   &= 5
\end{aligned}
$

The regular polygon has 5 sides.

children.question:

$
\begin{aligned}
4 \times a         &= 4(c - 9) \\\\

a                  &= \dfrac {4 \times (c - 9)} {4} \\\\
a                  &= \dfrac {\cancel {4} \times (c - 9)} {\cancel {4}} \\\\
a                  &= c - 9 \\\\
a                  &= 15 - 9 \\\\
a                  &= 6 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area}            &= a \times a \\\\
                        &= 6 \times 6 \\\\
                        &= 36 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$

a                       &= \dfrac {30 \times \cancel{2}} {\cancel {2}} \\\\
a                       &= 30 \ \text{p}  \\\\
\text {Price of pen}    &= 50 + a \\\\
                        &= 50 + 30 \\\\
                        &= 80 \ \text{p}
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: In the next game he scored enough goals to increase his mean to $4$. How many goals did he score in the seventh game?

solutionDetails.working:
Let goals scored in the seventh game $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {3 + 4 + 2 + 0 + 1 + 8 + a} {7}  &= 4 \\\\

$

children.question: I am making a scale model of The Eye-Full Tower, which is $120 \ \text{m}$ tall. If the scale is $1:50$, how long will the model be (in cm)?

solutionDetails.working:
Let length of the model $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
50 \ \text{m} : 1 \ \text{m}                    &= 120 \ \text{m} : a \ \text{m} \\\\
\dfrac {50} {1}                                 &= \dfrac {120} {a} \\\\
50 \times a                                     &= 120 \times 1 \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {120} {50} \ \text{m} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {120 \times 100} {50} \ \text{cm} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {120 \times 50 \times 2} {50} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {120 \times \cancel {50} \times 2} {\cancel {50}} \\\\
a                                               &= 120 \times 2 \\\\
a                                               &= 240 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Length of the model $= 240 \ \text{cm}$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**

Using ratio,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{tower}                                &:& \text{model} \\\\
= & 50 \ \text{m}                               &:& 1 \ \text{m} \\\\
= & 50 \ \text{m}                               &:& 1 \times 100 \ \text{cm} \\\\
= & 50                                          &:& 100 \\\\
= & 1                                           &:& \dfrac {100} {50} \\\\
= & 1 \times 120                                &:& \dfrac {100 \times 120} {50} \\\\
= & 120                                         &:& \dfrac {50 \times 2 \times 120} {50} \\\\
= & 120                                         &:& \dfrac {\cancel {50} \times 2 \times 120} {\cancel {50}} \\\\
= & 120                                         &:& 2 \times 120 \\\\
= & 120 \ \text{m}                              &:& 240 \ \text{cm}
\end{array}
$

Length of the model $= 240 \ \text{cm}$

children.question:
My friend Sanjay is making a scale model of the London Ear (a famous landmark in London).
The London Ear is $80 \ \text{m}$ tall and his model is $150 \ \text{cm}$ tall. What is the scale of the model, in its simplest form?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Scale}      &= \dfrac {\text{Length of the model}} {\text{Length of the tower}} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {150 \ \text{cm}} {80 \ \text{m}} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {150 \ \text{cm}} {80 \times 100 \ \text{cm}} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {50 \times 3} {80 \times 50 \times 2} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {\cancel {50} \times 3} {80 \times \cancel {50} \times 2} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {3} {80 \times 2} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {3} {160} \\\\
                  &= 3 : 160
\end{aligned}
$

My other friend Minka was doing some gardening when she snapped a bamboo cane. The cane was $2.05 \ \text{m}$ long and is now
$156 \ \text{cm}$ long. What length of cane snapped off?

solutionDetails.working:
The original length is given in $\text{meters}$ while the new length measurement is given in $\text{cm}$.

Let's convert the original measurements into $\text{cm}$.

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Original length of cane}         &= 2.05 \ \text{m} \\\\
                                        &= 2.05 \times 100 \ \text{cm} \\\\
                                        &= 2.05 \times 100 \\\\

\text {Legth of the cane snapped off}   &= \text {Original Length} - \text {New Length} \\\\
                                        &= 205 - 156 \\\\
                                        &= 49 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
Two runners are having a race. Gary starts running from the start line at $10 \ \text{m/s}$.
Two seconds later Andy starts running from the start line at $12 \ \text{m/s}$.

children.question: How long after Gary starts running does Andy catch up with him?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the time taken by Gary to catch up (in seconds) $= t$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
12 \times (t - 2)  &=  10 \times t \\\\
12t - 24           &=  10t \\\\
12t - 10t          &=  24 \\\\
2t                 &=  24 \\\\
t                  &=  \dfrac{24}{2} \\\\
t                  &=  \dfrac{12 \times 2}{2} \\\\
t                  &=  \dfrac{12 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
t                  &=  12 \text{ seconds}
\end{aligned}
$

Time taken $= 12 \text{ seconds}$

$17, 12, 8, 16, 2, 5, 10$

A set of four numbers $5, 7, 12$ and $X$ have a mean of $10$. What is $X$?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {5 + 7 + 12 + X} {4}         &= 10 \\\\
5 + 7 + 12 + X                      &= 10 \times 4 \\\\
24 + X                              &= 40 \\\\
X                                   &= 40 - 24 \\\\
X                                   &= 16
\end{aligned}
$

Value of $X = 16$

children.question: According to Nigella, when making a birthday cake, the perfect ratio of flour to sugar is $140:200$. What is this ratio in its simplest form?
I am making a scale model of my yacht, which is $9 \ \text{m}$ long. If the scale is $1:30$, how long will the model yacht be (in cm)?

solutionDetails.working:
Let length of the model yacht $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
1 \ \text{m} : 30 \ \text{m}                    &= a \ \text{m} : 9 \ \text{m} \\\\
\dfrac{1} {30}                                  &= \dfrac {a} {9} \\\\
a \times 30                                     &= 9 \times 1 \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {9} {30} \ \text{m} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {9 \times 100} {30} \ \text{cm} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times 3 \times 10 \times 10} {3 \times 10} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel 3 \times 10 \times \cancel {10}} {\cancel 3 \times \cancel {10}} \\\\
a                                               &= 30 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Length of the model yacht $= 30 \ \text{cm}$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**

Using ratio,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{yacht}                  &:& \text{model} \\\\
= & 30 \ \text{m}                 &:& 1 \ \text{m} \\\\
= & 30 \ \text{m}                 &:& 1 \times 100 \ \text{cm} \\\\
= & 30 \ \text{m}                 &:& 100 \ \text{cm} \\\\
= & 1                             &:& \dfrac {100} {30} \\\\
= & 1 \times 9                    &:& \dfrac {100 \times 9} {30} \\\\
= & 9                             &:& \dfrac {100 \times 3 \times 3} {30} \\\\
= & 9                             &:& \dfrac {10 \cancel 0 \times 3 \times \cancel 3} {\cancel 3 \cancel 0} \\\\
= & 9                             &:& 10 \times 3 \\\\
= & 9 \ \text{m}                  &:& 30 \ \text{cm}
\end{array}
$

Length of the model yacht $= 30 \ \text{cm}$

questions.question:
On my wall I want to put some stickers of David Cameron. The space I have available is $80 \ \text{cm}$ by $45 \ \text{cm}$
and the stickers are each $5 \ \text{cm}$ by $10 \ \text{cm}$. What is the maximum number of stickers I can fit on the wall?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of stickers}  &= \dfrac {\text{Area of the wall}} {\text{Area of a sticker}} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {80 \times 45} {10 \times 5} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {8 \times 10 \times 5 \times 9} {10 \times 5} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {8 \times \cancel {10} \times \cancel {5} \times 9} {\cancel {10} \times \cancel {5}} \\\\
                           &= 8 \times 9 \\\\
                           &= 72
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: What is the area of the triangle formed by these three points?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Base of the triangle}     &= \sqrt {(-1 - 2) ^ 2 + (1 - 1) ^ 2} \\\\
                                &= \sqrt {(-3) ^ 2 + 0 ^ 2} \\\\
                                &= \sqrt {9 + 0} \\\\
                                &= \sqrt {9} \\\\
                                &= 3 \\\\
\text{Height of the triangle}   &= 2 - 1 \\\\
                                &= 1 \\\\
\text{Area of the square}       &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times \text{(Base of the triangle)} \times \text{(Height of the triangle)} \\\\
                                &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 3 \times 1 \\\\
                                &= \dfrac {3} {2} \\\\
                                &= 1.5
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
What $5$-digit number has the following features:

If we put the numeral $1$ at the beginning, we get a number three times smaller than if we put the numeral $1$ at the end of the number?

In other words, if you think the answer is the number $34567$, then you want the number $134567$ to be one third of $345671$,
but it isn't, so what's the number?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number $= a$

The number by putting $1$ at the beginning $= 100000 + a$

The number by putting $1$ at the end $= 1 + 10a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
1 + 10a                       &= 3 \times ( 100000 + a ) \\\\
1 + 10a                       &= 300000 + 3a \\\\
10a - 3a                      &= 300000 - 1 \\\\
7a                            &= 299999 \\\\
a                             &= \dfrac {299999} {7} \\\\
a                             &= \dfrac {42857 \times 7} {7} \\\\
a                             &= \dfrac {42857 \times \cancel 7} {\cancel 7} \\\\
a                             &= 42857
\end{aligned}
$

The required $5$-digit number $= 42857$.
